ANU.name: Kamalini Lokuge
interest: EpidemiologyComplex Emergencies/Conflict SettingsEmerging Infectious Diseases including Ebola Virus DiseaseSexual and Gender-based ViolenceChild and Maternal Health
project: Dr Lokuge's current research includes: optimising public health interventions for COVID-19 control; documenting lessons learned from the response to the Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) outbreaks; operational research into services for gender-based violence and child protection in a range of settings; evaluating interventions for improving access to effective emergency obstetric care and access to contraception in Sierra Leone and other settings globally; developing methods and capacity for monitoring and evaluation of health programs in complex emergencies.
Please see “Related websites” section below for additional details.

ANDS-Grants.title: H1N1 Surveillance for H1N1 influenza 09 and evaluation of the impact of control measures in prisoner populations
funder: National Health and Medical Research Council

ANDS-Grants.description: Utilising Justice Reinvestment methodology, this project explores the conditions, governance and cultural appropriateness of re-investing resources otherwise spent on incarceration, into services to enhance juvenile offenders� ability to remain in their community to reduce further criminal behaviours and health costs associated with incarceration.
ANDS-Grants.title: Discovery Indigenous - Grant ID: IN130100048
subjects: youth at risk of contact with the criminal justice system

ANDS-Grants.description: Cervical cancer is much more common among Indigenous than other Australian women, however little is known about their cervical screening participation or outcomes. This study will use Pap Test Registers and other data sources to compare screening participation and outcomes for Indigenous and non-Indigenous women, and investigate whether cervical cancer incidence has decreased for Indigenous women in recent years, as it has done for non-Indigenous women in Australia.
ANDS-Grants.title: Cervical screening participation and outcomes for Indigenous Australian women
funder: National Health and Medical Research Council
subjects: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health
